COVID-19 & #DistanceLearning have further exposed persistent inequities afflicting students & families in low-income communities & Black & Latinx communities. Join Silicon Valley Community Foundation this Monday at 10 a.m. PT to hear from the Superintendents of Schools for San Mateo County Office of Education & Santa Clara County Office of Education.

These local leaders in education will join SVCF's VP of Strategic Initiatives & Partnerships to discuss the current state of public education & the role of #philanthropy in supporting students during the pandemic & beyond. Register here & join us on September 14 at 10 a.m. PT: https://siliconvalleycf.zoom.us/webinar/register/1015985455350/WN_Bn4T_QdQSj2S0E7uZihTvw?utm_medium=app_email&utm_source=lp_app&utm_source=task_activity

post_text:
We are partnering with CAELI and other county offices of education to host “A Call to Action for Educational Leaders,” a free, five-part webinar series designed by and for California education leaders on integrating environmental literacy across school systems.

These 60 minute webinars will begin with a 30 minute presentation of promising practices and curated, field-tested tools and resources. The second half will allow for facilitated discussions, networking, and addressing problems of practice.

Learn more at https://ca-eli.org/webinar/

#environmentalliteracy

post_text:
"Back to school" season in #SiliconValley looks different than any other school year. #COVID19 has made distance learning the default & exposes the persistent inequities that afflict students & families in low-income communities & Black & Latinx communities.

Join Superintendent Nancy Magee on Monday, September 14, with Silicon Valley Community Foundation and Santa Clara County Superintendent Mary Ann Dewan to discuss the current state of local public education & offer ideas about how our philanthropic community can support public school students during the pandemic & beyond.

Register here & join us on September 14: https://siliconvalleycf.zoom.us/webinar/register/1015985455350/WN_Bn4T_QdQSj2S0E7uZihTvw?utm_medium=app_email&utm_source=lp_app&utm_source=task_activity

post_text:
The climate crisis, growing inequality, systemic racism, and the pandemic are threatening our lives and our life support systems.

Join the Citizens Environmental Council of Burlingame on Wednesday, September 16 from 7-8pm for a discussion on "Living Locally" and the importance of vital connections. Admission is free. Pre-register at https://bit.ly/3jiAO50.
shared_text:
Citizens Environmental Council of Burlingame
August 31 at 12:01 AM ·

Join us on Wed. Sept. 16, 7-8 p.m., when Matt Biggar, Ph.D., offers guidance and invites discussion on the importance of vital connections. This program, "Living Locally," will examine the deepening crisis of disconnectedness due to the climate crisis, growing inequality, systemic racism and the pandemic, and discuss the importance of strengthening connections. Admission is free, but you must pre-register at https://bit.ly/3jiAO50.

post_text:
As of August 27, San Mateo County is holding strong with a self-response rate of 76.9% - however that still leaves 23.1% of the county not counted!

If just 10% of our county is not counted in this census, that could mean up to $76,000,000 a year we would not receive for the next 10 years.

Complete the #2020Census at my2020census.gov or 844-330-2020.

post_text:
Last night, the San Mateo County Board of Education and Superintendent of Schools Nancy Magee passed a joint resolution endorsing September 15 to October 15 as National Hispanic Heritage Month and Latinx Heritage Month.

Members of the Latinx community have made countless contributions to the United States' economy and culture, especially in San Mateo County. We look forward to highlighting their diversity and history over the next month, and during the course of the 2020-21 school year!

Read the full resolution at https://bit.ly/SMCOEresolutions

#HispanicHeritageMonth #LatinxHeritageMonth

SMCOE.ORG
Recent Resolutions - San Mateo County Office of Education

Last week the U.S. Census Bureau began sending a 7th mailer including a paper questionnaire to the census tracts highlighted in yellow (those that have not yet responded in tracts with a self-response rate of 65% or lower on July 28).

Emails will be sent to neighborhoods with a response rate below 50% & may include those who have already responded.

Complete the #2020Census at my2020census.gov or 844-330-2020.

Learn more at https://bit.ly/34XdA0c.

Research shows that 50% of our child care slots are at risk of disappearing permanently without support.

Congresswoman Jackie Speier is hosting a virtual town hall about child care today at 6pm to hear how parents and child care providers are adjusting to our new reality and what challenges they are facing.

Join the town hall at https://bit.ly/2QKGSqA

#childcare #COVID19

post_text:
We are excited to announce that we have received a $5 million grant from the California Department of Education to support inclusive early learning and care programs in San Mateo County!

The grant will be used to strengthen inclusive early learning settings, where children with and without special needs learn and play together, build relationships and friendships, and develop a sense of belonging and membership.

We are looking forward to collaborating with the CDE, school districts, and local agencies to give all infants and toddlers high quality experiences! Read more at https://bit.ly/31Ljtvw.

Jefferson Elementary School District San Mateo-Foster City School District San Bruno Park School District Cabrillo Unified School District

#earlylearning #earlychildhoodeducation #earlychildhood #inclusion #inclusionmatters

Where do you wear a mask? Everywhere you go.
• In all public indoor spaces
• At doctor and all other healthcare offices
• On public transportation
• In shared spaces at work
• Outdoors when you can’t be 6 feet apart from others
Don’t forget your mask!
Get more info on California's face covering mandate: covid19.ca.gov.

#MaskUpSMC

post_text:
In July, the San Mateo County Board of Supervisors allocated $2M of CARES Act funds to the Child Care Relief Fund. Eligibility for this grant program is limited to licensed child care centers and family child care homes as well as license-exempt public recreation and school-district operated programs in the county that have been adversely impacted by COVID-19.

Grants will cover one month of operating expenses up to $10,000 for family child care homes and $55,000 for child care centers. Multi-site agencies are eligible for one grant.

The program will prioritize child care programs that serve the most vulnerable San Mateo County residents, demonstrate fiscal sustainability, and participate in existing county initiatives such as The Big Lift and Quality Counts.

The application opens today, Monday, August 24 at 9am. All applications must be received by Friday, September 4 at 5pm.

For more information and to apply: Visit bit.ly/SMC_ChildCareRelief.

Update from the County of San Mateo - Government: The San Mateo County Supervisors proclaim a local emergency as CAL FIRE CZU San Mateo-Santa Cruz Unit crews battle wildfires in Loma Mar and South Coast area; mandatory evacuations ordered for threatened communities, more evacuation warnings expected.

The Board voted 5-0 in an emergency session today to approve the proclamation, which makes the County eligible for federal reimbursement for some costs associated with the response and additional flexibility for staffing and purchasing.

More here: https://bit.ly/2EfDGjV

From County of San Mateo - Government: The CZU AUGUST LIGHTNING COMPLEX fires continued to actively burn throughout the night due to low relative humidities, high night-time temperatures and limited resources. Approximately 9,000 acres in San Mateo County, 0% contained at this time.

CAL FIRE CZU San Mateo-Santa Cruz Unit is using all available resources to get the fires under control.
The map below shows the current evacuation areas, but it could expand.

PLEASE BE PREPARED.

• For information on how to prepare & evacuate for a wildfire, go to: https://www.readyforwildfire.org/prepa…/go-evacuation-guide/.
• To receive emergency alerts, sign up at: www.smcalert.info.
• View the most current evacuation information at:
www.smco.community.zonehaven.com.
• Receive email updates from CAL FIRE: https://tinyurl.com/czulightning

post_text:
The San Mateo County Board of Supervisors approved an emergency ordinance to impose fines for businesses and individuals who violate the county's and state's public health orders, including refusing to wear a face covering.

- First offense: $100
- Second: $200
- Third: $500

Commercial entities risk a minimum fine of $250 and a maximum of $3,000 per violation depending on the gravity of the health risk.

More info here: https://bit.ly/3gw6IK5.

Impact of Placement on State Monitoring List on San Mateo County Schools - San Mateo County Office of Education
text:
San Mateo County was formally placed on the State’s monitoring list as of Sunday, August 2, 2020, somewhat limiting the flexibility of local schools to pursue various in-person learning options to start the 2020-21 school year.

Read our media release to learn more about how this impacts TK-12 public and private schools: https://bit.ly/3i2qVaP.

#ReopeningSchools

post_text:
As of Aug. 1 mid-day, the state has informed San Mateo County that due to being more than 3 days on the COVID monitoring list, specific indoor businesses must cease operations, unless they can be modified to operate outside or by pick-up. Beginning 12:01 a.m. Sunday, Aug. 2, 2020, the state order to close or move outside applies to the following businesses:
• Gyms and fitness centers
• Places of worship and cultural ceremonies, like weddings and funerals
• Offices for non-critical infrastructure sectors
• Personal care services, like nail salons and body waxing
• Hair salons and barbershops
• Shopping malls
Shops that offer tattoos, piercings, and electrolysis may not be operated outdoors and must close.
Businesses should visit the state website for industry guidance: https://covid19.ca.gov/roadmap-counties/#track-data
Information about the County of San Mateo’s response to COVID-19 is at www.smcgov.org.

The California Department of Education has just released an online resource to help local educational agencies (LEAs) address questions related to distance learning: https://www.cde.ca.gov/ci/cr/dl/distlearningfaqs.asp.

More of your questions about safely returning to on-campus learning can be answered through the San Mateo County's Pandemic Recovery Framework for Schools. Learn more at https://bit.ly/SMCframework.

#ReopeningSchools
shared_text:
California Department of Education
July 28 at 7:16 PM ·

CDE has just released an online resource to help local educational agencies (LEAs) address questions related to distance learning pursuant to California Education Code 43500–43511 (resulting from Senate Bill 98). These Frequently Asked Questions (FAQs) can be found on the CDE Distance Learning FAQs web page at https://www.cde.ca.gov/ci/cr/dl/distlearningfaqs.asp, and more FAQs will follow in the coming days.

Later this week, CDE will also release the Learning Continuity Plan Template, Instructions, and Guidance in addition to an FAQ for LEAs. The template is intended to support the planning that districts are already doing as they prepare to begin another academic year and hold to the promises of the Local Control Funding Formula. The Learning Continuity Plan replaces the LCAP for the 2020-21 school year.

As a reminder, CDE will host two upcoming webinars for LEAs to better understand Learning Continuity and Attendance Plans. Details can be found here: https://www.cde.ca.gov/fg/aa/lc/tuesdaysat2.asp.

post_text: Thank you to the County of San Mateo - Government's Probation staff! We truly appreciate your support to make sure these students continue receiving a quality education.
shared_text:
County of San Mateo - Government
July 24 at 5:02 PM ·

The COVID-19 pandemic has forced everyone in every corner of our society to make major changes to how we live our every day lives.

Take inside the County's Youth Services Center-Juvenile Hall and Camp Kemp, for example, where Probation Department staff fill the void for youth whose in-person contact with their family and teachers has been reduced to videoconferencing due to COVID-19 health guidelines.

These group supervisors are providing counseling sessions and updates about the pandemic, including the mandate to wear face coverings. They are also leading activities such as gardening and art projects, cooking demonstrations and game nights to keep youth engaged and active.

During the shelter in place, Probation staff also worked with school officials to get online classes set up.

Our Probation Department continues to do excellent work fulfilling their mission of enhancing community safety and reducing crime through offender accountability and rehabilitation while implementing COVID-19 guidelines to keep everyone safe and healthy.

Immigrants are working on the front lines of the #COVID19 crisis, risking their health and well-being every day to keep our society going. And yet, many immigrants were left out of the CARES Act relief.

The San Mateo County Immigrant Relief Fund provides financial support to immigrant families left out of the federal government’s relief efforts. Immigrant families may be eligible to receive a $1,000 grant to help in this time of crisis.

https://missionassetfund.org/immigrant-families-grant-sm/

Mission Asset Fund Faith in Action Bay Area Samaritan House Legal Aid Society of San Mateo County

Registration is now open for our 2020-22 ACT II program, where school administrators can earn their clear administrative services credential!

ACT II is designed to focus on a leader's current work, to support her/him in developing pertinent and impactful leadership goals, and to provide four-hours coaching a month from an experienced administrator. The program has been aligned to our current teaching and leading environment amongst the implications of COVID-19 and the call for clear and committed anti-racists educational systems.

Learn more at https://bit.ly/3fy7xll and register at https://bit.ly/2ZumvD5.

Inspiring Summers — an initiative of The Big Lift — is up and running following the San Mateo County Pandemic Recovery Framework and health partners to guide safety protocols intended to reduce the risk of spread of COVID-19 in schools.

Graduations are being held at locations across the county this week and next to celebrate participants’ achievements.

Outdoor Learning is a time-tested approach to keeping school open during a pandemic.

Join us on Tuesday, July 21, from 12:30-1:30pm to learn how to develop a plan for using outdoor space. Hear from our experts at the County Office of Education as well as San Mateo County school communities that are making this transition.

More information at https://bit.ly/SMCframework

#outdoorlearning Franklin D. Roosevelt K-8 PTA Green Hills PTA Spring Valley PTA Taylor Middle School PTA San Mateo Park PTA Fiesta Gardens PTA George Hall PTA Meadow Heights Elementary PTA

We are so proud to work with Green Schoolyards America, Lawrence Hall of Science, Ten Strands, and other partners to support schools in developing #outdoorlearning opportunities!

Check out https://bit.ly/3gUC4dk and Green Schoolyards America's website at https://bit.ly/COVID-OutdoorLearning for more resources.
shared_text:
GREENSCHOOLYARDS.ORG
COVID-19 Outdoor Learning — Green Schoolyards America

Green Schoolyards America
July 10 at 8:21 PM ·

Over the last few months, Green Schoolyards America has been collaborating with Lawrence Hall of Science, San Mateo County Office of Education, Ten Strands, and other fantastic partners to launch a National COVID-19 Outdoor Learning Initiative, designed to help schools reopen in the fall using outdoor classroom spaces as healthy, safe places for children to spend their day.

This is a collective impact effort, and we invite you to join us! Please check out our website at the link below, and sign up for a working group if you'd like to help! https://bit.ly/COVID-OutdoorLearning

July 10 at 12:13 AM ·

We have LIFTOFF! This week we celebrate Belle Air’s Big Lift Inspiring Summers program!!

The Inspiring Summers’ team is doing an incredible job welcoming scholars, making them feel comfortable and safe, as well as reassuring parents. This terrific four-week program has even created a beautiful and informative website with helpful information.

Congratulations to Belle Air teachers and leaders on your dedication to our kids and families! #LiftWithUs

post_text:
Are you in North San Mateo County and looking to start a career in early childhood education and care?

Apply for the Teacher Pipeline Project, which bundles ECE courses with wraparound support to increase the number of early learning educators in the Bay Area. Classes start mid-August!
shared_text:
COMMUNITYEQUITYCOLLABORATIVE.ORG
North County Teacher Pipeline Project

Community Equity Collaborative
July 9 at 12:59 AM ·

Community Equity Collaborative is excited to announce the launch of our Teacher Pipeline Project in North San Mateo County in partnership with Skyline College. Our program provides pathways into early learning careers through online Early Childhood Education courses offered with wrap-around resources and support. For more information on classes starting in mid-August, visit our website. Registration is open NOW! http://www.communityequitycollaborative.org/north-county-teacher-pipeline-project.html

We are so grateful for this partnership, Peninsula Clean Energy! And excited to see that the Clean Energy Teacher Fellowship is so popular that it is already at capacity!

Spots are still available in other topics, however, including zero waste, sustainable watersheds, and transportation. Learn more and apply at http://bit.ly/2QZ1Th6.
shared_text:
Peninsula Clean Energy
June 25 at 5:44 PM ·

Educating the next generation is crucial for the future of clean energy.

To help educators bring environmental literacy into classrooms, we are funding a Clean Energy Teacher Fellowship in partnership with the San Mateo County Office of Education.

Read about our initiative: https://www.peninsulacleanenergy.com/cir-eduation/
text:
We are so grateful for this partnership, Peninsula Clean Energy! And excited to see that the Clean Energy Teacher Fellowship is so popular that it is already at capacity!

Peninsula Clean Energy
June 25 at 5:44 PM ·

Educating the next generation is crucial for the future of clean energy.

To help educators bring environmental literacy into classrooms, we are funding a Clean Energy Teacher Fellowship in partnership with the San Mateo County Office of Education.

Read about our initiative: https://www.peninsulacleanenergy.com/cir-eduation/

post_text:
"Equitable access needs to be reflected in every facet of our educational system, including budget, staffing, resource allocation and many other spaces. More resources need to be directed toward marginalized students and communities. These decisions must be made and these changes must be enacted to ensure all of our students have access to the resources they need to eventually contribute effectively to our society."

Jefferson Union High School District Board President Kalimah Salahuddin and San Mateo County Board of Education President Hector Camacho, Jr., published an inspiring opinion piece in the San Mateo Daily Journal sharing how the San Mateo County School Boards Association recently launched the Equity Network to build a more equitable educational system.

https://bit.ly/2A10eTz

What is the difference between a nonracist and antiracist? How do I talk to my child about racism? What resources are there to discuss racism in the classroom?

As educators, we are compelled to confront the racism and injustice, but it might be difficult to know where to start. Find a curated list of resources and organizations on our website to help your children or students embrace antiracism: https://bit.ly/2NpnPjS.

Today is the first day all employees began returning to our main office at 101 Twin Dolphin Drive!

Following the Four Pillars described in the Pandemic Recovery Framework for Schools, staff are being screened upon entry, wearing masks while inside the office, and maintaining physical distancing. While the office is not open yet to the public, staff were excited to see each other after months of working virtually.

Unfamiliar with the Pandemic Recovery Framework for Schools? You can find more information on the framework at https://bit.ly/SMCframework.

post_text:
The San Mateo County Office of Education celebrates the Supreme Court's decision to continue the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (#DACA) program!

This means that California can:
- offer in-state tuition and financial aid to undocumented students
- allow undocumented people to have Driver’s Licenses
- allow undocumented people to apply for professional licenses
- provide health insurance to children under 18 and prenatal care to anyone, regardless of their immigration status

Learn more about what this means for San Mateo County students and families on our website: https://bit.ly/2V08kTT

post_text: Update from the County of San Mateo - Government: The state has granted San Mateo County its request for a variance, which will allow San Mateo County Health Officer Dr. Scott Morrow to issue a new order addressing additional businesses and activities.
shared_text:
County of San Mateo - Government is sharing a COVID-19 Update.
June 16 at 10:47 PM ·

NEWS: The state has granted San Mateo County its request for a variance, which will allow San Mateo County Health Officer Dr. Scott Morrow to issue a new order addressing additional businesses and activities.

Until the new order takes effect, San Mateo County remains in early Stage 2 of the Resilience Roadmap and bound by the current health order. The new order is expected to be issued this week, which will make clear what business may open and what guidelines they must follow.

“This is great news for so many of the thousands of small businesses that are truly the backbone of our local economy, especially in East Palo Alto and North Fair Oaks,” said Board President Warren Slocum, whose District 4 includes both communities.

“People want to get back to work. That said, it’s up to all of us to continue to wear face coverings and to maintain social distancing so we can continue to reopen both the economy and our social lives in a safe manner.”

More COVID-19 news and information here: www.smcgov.org.

post_text:
State Superintendent Tony Thurmond is releasing the California Department of Education's guidance document, “Stronger Together: A Guidebook for the Safe Reopening of California’s Public Schools."

During a news conference today at 11:15 a.m. on Facebook Live, Thurmond and CDE leaders will walk through the document’s key tools and recommendations.
shared_text:
California Department of Education
June 6 at 4:49 PM ·

Reminder: State Superintendent Tony Thurmond will release the CDE guidance document, “Stronger Together: A Guidebook for the Safe Reopening of California’s Public Schools,” on Monday, June 8. During a news conference Monday at 11:15 a.m. on Facebook Live, Thurmond and CDE leaders will walk through the document’s key tools and recommendations.

This guidance will serve as a road map of recommendations for schools as they work with their local public health officials and school communities to navigate next steps. Educational leaders will find recommendations for face coverings, physical distancing, and symptom screening should schools plan to provide some form of in-person instruction and distance learning. The document will also provide in-depth considerations for designing high-quality and equitable instructional practices for all students.

Research suggests that racism and prejudice begins at a young age. We can address this bias by acknowledging and naming race and racism with children as early and as often as possible.

The Association of California School Administrators has curated a list of children's books to help us initiate these critical conversations and model what it means to resist and dismantle oppression: https://bit.ly/2XxGRL1

#respect247

post_text:
How can SEL advance racial justice, address trauma, and reduce bias? California educators, join the Advance Social and Emotional Learning in California WikiWisdom Forum before it closes on June 5th to add your voice and ideas: https://sel.wikiwisdomforum.com.

State Superintendent Tony Thurmond, First Partner Jennifer Siebel Newsom, and State Board of Education President Linda Darling-Hammond launched the #AdvanceSELinCA campaign last month to engage educators, school leaders, and families in a wider conversation about how to advance, elevate, and spur action on Social and Emotional Learning (SEL) in California.

The campaign will run from May-August of this year, led by Beyond Differences in partnership with Education First.

Read more: https://www.cde.ca.gov/nr/ne/yr20/yr20rel37.asp.
#socialandemotionallearning #socialemotionallearning

post_text:
Our county is unique, in that we have 20 incorporated cities and lots of unincorporated areas as well. Together in San Mateo County, #EveryoneCounts on the #2020Census.

text:

post_text:
“We must be the change we wish to see in the world.” (Mahatma Gandhi)

Racist language and behavior can have a profound and lasting impact on children and adds to the stress they are experiencing as a result of the COVID-19 health crisis. Set an example for future generations by showing kindness, respect, and other values we can all be proud of.

Join us in sharing this message to make San Mateo County a safe place for all people, especially children and youth. #respect247

post_text:
We are excited to award $400,000 in COVID-19 Education Partnership funds to 13 public school districts in San Mateo County!

The Bayshore School
Belmont-Redwood Shores SD
Cabrillo Unified School District
Jefferson Elementary School District
Jefferson Union High School District
Pescadero Schools (La Honda-Pescadero Unified School District)
Pacifica School District
Redwood City School District
San Bruno Park School District
San Carlos School District
San Mateo-Foster City School District
Sequoia Union High School District
South San Francisco Unified School District

These funds, seeded by Silicon Valley Community Foundation and matched by Genentech, will help school districts address immediate challenges and longer-term recovery efforts related to #COVID19. Learn more at https://bit.ly/3cWezz0.

Donations are still being accepted, no matter how large or small. Visit www.smcoe.org/cep to learn more or donate if you are able.

It is so touching to hear #SanMateoCounty teachers successfully pivot to #distancelearning and appreciate any opportunity they get to connect with their students!

Our #COVID19 Education Partnership with the Silicon Valley Community Foundation was developed to help teachers continue to connect and support students' learning during these tough times. Learn more at www.smcoe.org/cep.
shared_text:
YOUTUBE.COM
Exchanges: Teachers & Virtual Classrooms

The Midpen Media Center
May 15 at 5:03 PM ·

New program available to view now on our Youtube! Seven teachers from schools in Palo Alto, East Palo Alto, Mountain View, Fremont, and San Francisco gather on Zoom to exchange their experiences since their brick & mortar schools closed down. What have they learned? What does it mean to be a teacher during the shelter-in-place times of the Covid-19 virus?

post_text:
“No act of kindness no matter how small is ever wasted.” (Aesop)

Make a goal to do one act of kindness to brighten up someone else's day, and encourage your family and/or students to do the same. Thank someone who helped you, write a letter to a friend, give someone at home a hug, or say hello to others you meet. The sky's the limit!

Join us in sharing this message to make San Mateo County a safe place for all people, especially children and youth. #respect247

Disaster Relief Assistance for Immigrants (DRAI)

First 5 San Mateo County
May 18 at 6:34 PM ·

Applications for the Disaster Recovery Assistance to Immigrants Program (DRAI) begin today! DRAI provides state-funded disaster relief assistance to undocumented adults who are not eligible for other forms of assistance due to their immigration status. Call the hotline at 866-490-3899 to apply. Visit here for more information about the program and frequently asked questions: https://www.catholiccharitiessf.org/covid-19-relief/drai.html

post_text:
The County of San Mateo - Government expanded the number of COVID-19 testing sites operated by Verily to include locations in East Palo Alto and Daly City on a rotating schedule. Verily will continue to operate its San Mateo Event Center site on Mondays and Tuesdays, while adding the old Serramonte High School campus in Daly City on Wednesdays and Thursdays and the Lewis and Joan Platt East Palo Alto Family YMCA on Fridays and Saturdays.

Testing is free and available without restriction to anyone, though an appointment is required in advance. To make an appointment, residents can visit Project Baseline's website at https://bit.ly/2xk73OL.

#COVID19

Join the California Department of Education for a webinar discussing the safe re-opening of schools for in-person learning.

The webinar will include updates from the CDE on guidance for schools, presentations by districts that are developing plans on re-opening, and Q&A. This webinar will be streamed on Facebook Live and Zoom. Stay tuned for more details and a Zoom link.
shared_text:
California Department of Education is sharing a COVID-19 Update.

On Thursday May 21st, the Paul K. Longmore Institute on Disability at San Francisco State University is hosting a Superfest Disability Film Festival Showcase specifically geared for kids!

Join in and start a conversation about disability as a family, or let us teach the kids for an hour. Films are most suited for ages 5-10, but anyone can enjoy!
Films will play with audio description and captioning. Program will have live captioning and ASL.
Thursday, May 21st at 10:30-11:30 A.M. PT
To register visit: tinyurl.com/SuperfestKids

post_text:
Coinciding with the spread of #COVID19 has been a deplorable rise in anti-Asian American and Pacific Islander (AAPI) discrimination in the United States and San Mateo County. Children have not been immune.

The San Mateo County Office of Education and Board of Education is making a stand against anti-AAPI racism by passing a resolution at its May 4 meeting condemning hate speech and behavior and calling for unity. Read the full resolution at https://bit.ly/2zq4ZFN.

Join us in sharing this message to make San Mateo County a safe place for all people, especially children and youth. #respect247

post_text:
On behalf of San Mateo County schools, we are so grateful for Genentech's support in serving students across the county!

Schools everywhere are facing difficult budget decisions due to the #COVID19 pandemic. Learn how you can help at www.smcoe.org/cep and invite others to do the same!
shared_text:
GENE.COM
3 Ways We’re Giving During COVID-19

Genentech
May 12 at 3:00 PM ·

Doing our part during the COVID-19 crisis means going beyond our vital day-to-day work to advance science. Today, we’re committing $42 million to provide immediate and long-term support to our communities, including low-income households and people of color disproportionately impacted by the pandemic.

These funds are being directed nationally, regionally and locally to organizations like Direct Relief, Silicon Valley Community Foundation, San Francisco Foundation and Boys & Girls Clubs of Oceanside that are supporting critical relief and recovery efforts. Learn more: https://bit.ly/3dxPBWq

post_text:
“I wanted to take a minute to thank every teacher, every administrator, every employee of schools in San Mateo County to thank you. Thank you for what you do for children each and every day, and the extraordinary work you are doing during the COVID-19 pause.”

U.S. Representative Jackie Speier entered a resolution into the Congressional Record honoring San Mateo County school staff during National Teacher Appreciation Month. Thank you for your heartfelt appreciation for all teachers and school staff in San Mateo County!

#TeacherAppreciationMonth #COVID19 #distancelearning
shared_text:
Congresswoman Jackie Speier
May 8 at 7:50 PM ·

May is National Teacher Appreciation Month and I want to honor every teacher, administrator, employee and contractor in all San Mateo County school districts who together prepare our children to grow into educated and contributing members of our society. They rise to the occasion even under the most challenging and unprecedented conditions they are facing in the midst of the coronavirus pandemic.

post_text:
San Mateo County Health Public Health Officer Dr. Scott Morrow has issued a new order permitting certain “highly regulated” gatherings of vehicles, designed to allow schools to host modified graduation ceremonies.

For gatherings of ten or more vehicles, the order requires the occupants of the vehicle to be members of the same household, not to exit the vehicle at the gathering except to use a restroom or collect an item such as a diploma, and, if the windows are open, to wear face coverings. Learn more at https://www.smcoe.org/other/covid-19-response-and-resources/

#covid19 #classof2020 #classof2020strong

Our San Mateo County Outdoor Education naturalists bring the Outdoor Education program to students who aren’t able to attend due to the shelter-in-place order.

Note that our naturalists have been isolating and interacting with each other only for the past month. They are being safe and sheltering in place, just like you, while delivering the Outdoor Education experience to San Mateo County students.

As the livestream begins, please remember to follow our social media policy: do not post comments that are inappropriate or unrelated to the topic at hand. Posts that violate this policy will be deleted. Read our full social media policy on the About tab.

post_text:
The CDE's Early Learning and Care Division (ELCD) and Fiscal Administrative Services Division released guidance on funding for cleaning and supplies for child care providers. These funds will be distributed to Resource and Referral (R&R) agencies who will then distribute funding and resources to providers in their area. In addition, the ELCD has provided guidance to R&R agencies and other contractors about existing funding that can be allocated for cleaning supplies and personal protective equipment to align with the established COVID-19 guidelines on health and safety practices in child care settings.

Read more: https://www.cde.ca.gov/sp/cd/ci/mb2011.asp
Find more COVID-19 guidance for early learning and care programs here: https://www.cde.ca.gov/sp/cd/re/elcdcovid19.asp.

Please join the Virtual Support Circle for Educators During COVID-19 on Facebook Live this Thursday, May 7, at 4 p.m.

California Department of Education
May 5 at 5:18 PM ·

State Superintendent Tony Thurmond understands many educators are feeling overwhelmed during this time of distance learning and wants to find ways to provide support through this challenge. Please join the Virtual Support Circle for Educators During COVID-19 on Facebook Live this Thursday, May 7, at 4 p.m.

post_text:
Our San Mateo County Outdoor Education naturalists bring the Outdoor Education program to students who aren’t able to attend due to the shelter-in-place order.

Note that our naturalists have been isolating and interacting with each other only for the past month. They are being safe and sheltering in place, just like you, while delivering the Outdoor Education experience to San Mateo County students.

As the livestream begins, please remember to follow our social media policy: do not post comments that are inappropriate or unrelated to the topic at hand. Posts that violate this policy will be deleted. Read our full social media policy on the About tab.

post_text:
San Mateo County currently has the highest response rates in the entire state of California at 65.4 percent.
However, that means there is still another 34.6 percent of our households that need to be counted!

Without everyone being counted, we could lose federal funding for our most critical programs like health care, schools, food assistance, and emergency services. It only take 10 minutes and affects the next 10 years.

There are three ways you can respond:
✔️online at my2020census.gov
✔️phone at 844-330-2020
✔️mail

Let’s all do our part and help our communities because #EveryoneCounts!

post_text:
Our San Mateo County Outdoor Education naturalists bring the Outdoor Education program to students who aren’t able to attend due to the shelter-in-place order.

Note that our naturalists have been isolating and interacting with each other only for the past month. They are being safe and sheltering in place, just like you, while delivering the Outdoor Education experience to San Mateo County students.

As the livestream begins, please remember to follow our social media policy: do not post comments that are inappropriate or unrelated to the topic at hand. Posts that violate this policy will be deleted. Read our full social media policy on the About tab.

post_text:
If you have been looking for an opportunity to support San Mateo County students and schools impacted by COVID-19 and school closures, today is your day.

The COVID-19 Education Fund has just been launched to help districts provide needed distance learning, nutritional, mental health, and other support to students and their families. Learn/donate on the San Mateo County Office of Education website: www.smcoe.org/cep

post_text:
Bay Area public health officers issued revised shelter-in-place orders that largely keep the current restrictions in place and extend them through May 31, 2020.

The new order includes limited easing of specific restrictions for a small number of lower-risk activities, including construction, outdoor businesses, and recreation activities at shared outdoor facilities.

Read the announcement from the County of San Mateo - Government: https://bit.ly/3cXzMYT
Read the full order: https://bit.ly/2YjYqyO
shared_text:

April 29 at 6:49 PM ·

post_text:
San Mateo County Behavioral Health & Recovery Services' Diversity and Equity Council is hosting a town hall on Race & Coronavirus this Friday at 11am.

The town hall will include a discussion on COVID-19-related impacts on people of color, LGBTQ+, and low-income communities, as well as a discussion on priorities and strategies to support communities across San Mateo County. Register today at https://bit.ly/2YiKy8a

San Mateo County Health StarVista Bay Area Community Health Advisory Council Catholic Charities Get Healthy San Mateo County

Today we published our second issue of our weekly Distance Learning Support newsletter! This week's issue addresses xenophobia and racism amid #COVID19, teaches how to use scientific observations to develop oral language skills, and shares other resources.

Read the issue at https://bit.ly/2Ye0hoM and subscribe at https://bit.ly/3ay5lHi.

#distancelearning

We recognize that not all heroes wear capes - some heroes wear masks. Thank you to all of the heroes on the front lines responding to #COVID19!

We all can help these heroes by continuing to practice physical distancing and other recommendations from San Mateo County Health. You can also support them and our communities by taking the #2020Census at my2020Census.gov. #EveryoneCountsSMC #NationalSuperheroDay

Note that our naturalists have been isolating and interacting with each other only for the past month. They are being safe and sheltering in place, just like you, while delivering the Outdoor Education experience to San Mateo County students.

As the livestream begins, please remember to follow our social media policy: do not post comments that are inappropriate or unrelated to the topic at hand. Posts that violate this policy will be deleted. Read our full social media policy on the About tab.

post_text:
As we wrap up #EarthWeek, please enjoy these Earth Day haikus created by our staff!

Haiku is a form of poetry that uses 17 syllables arranged in three lines: first line, 5 syllables; second line, 7 syllables; third line, 5 syllables.

Read more haikus at https://bit.ly/2Y2w4ZR and write your own to express what nature means to you!

#EarthDayAtHome #EarthDay2020 #NationalPoetryMonth

post_text:
State Superintendent Tony Thurmond commended yesterday’s executive order by California Governor Gavin Newsom that allows schools to focus on the impacts of campus closures as a result of COVID-19 and their mitigation plans for when students return this fall. The executive order does this by extending the deadline for school districts and charter schools to submit upcoming Local Control and Accountability Plans (LCAP) which are long-range planning documents tied to budget projections.
Read more: https://bit.ly/351Yq7O
Read the executive order here: https://bit.ly/2KzoVZ8
shared_text:
California Department of Education
April 24 at 6:45 PM ·

State Superintendent Tony Thurmond commended yesterday’s executive order by California Governor Gavin Newsom that allows schools to focus on the impacts of campus closures as a result of COVID-19 and their mitigation plans for when students return this fall. The executive order does this by extending the deadline for school districts and charter schools to submit upcoming Local Control and Accountability Plans (LCAP) which are long-range planning documents tied to budget projections.

Read more: https://www.cde.ca.gov/nr/ne/yr20/yr20rel25.asp

Read the executive order here: https://www.gov.ca.gov/2020/04/23/governor-newsom-issues-executive-order-empowering-schools-to-focus-on-covid-19-response-and-transparency/

post_text:
Thank you, The Big Lift, for recognizing Karla and her work to help early learning teachers and family support practitioners keep families engaged!

Karla Rodriguez is our Project Specialist, Early Childhood Language Development. Among other things, she has been facilitating an early learning family engagement community of practice every Tuesday at 2pm to help the early learning community share experiences, best practices, and concrete resources to strengthen family engagement.

Interested? Join her for the next network meeting at https://zoom.us/meeting/register/v5MrceuvrzkpE3i3zKRx0y3oeJhrlaY5fg?fbclid=IwAR1pgmE3e7A2r2SI_iPa53mqZHS_FCzAY37bA5uKjlSQ-n_xikf2aKLokdc
shared_text:
The Big Lift
April 23 at 11:05 PM ·

We have LIFTOFF! This week we celebrate Karla Rodriguez, San Mateo County Office of Education Project Specialist, Early Childhood Language Development!

Karla is facilitating San Mateo County's weekly early learning family engagement community of practice! This professional network of teachers and family support practitioners collaborate on shared experiences, best practices, and concrete resources to strengthen family engagement.

If you might find this connection helpful, then please join us for these weekly conversations to support families!

You can register at: https://zoom.us/meeting/register/v5MrceuvrzkpE3i3zKRx0y3oeJhrlaY5fg

Congratulations to Karla for a timely and impactful initiative! #LiftWithUs

County of San Mateo - Government
Silicon Valley Community Foundation

post_text:
Thank you Silicon Valley Community Foundation and Genentech for seeding the COVID-19 Education Partnership to support local districts and students!

More about the partnership can be found on our website at www.smcoe.org/cep.

#COVID19Response #WeAreInThisTogether
shared_text:
Silicon Valley Community Foundation
April 22 at 6:45 PM ·

We are pleased to announce the launch of the COVID-19 Education Partnership, an initiative in collaboration with the San Mateo County Office of Education & the Santa Clara County Office of Education to support the needs of local education systems through the current crisis.

Our foundation has seeded the fund with an initial $1 million, & would also like to extend thanks to Genentech for their matching donation. Learn more about how the partnership will expand the capacity of local school districts & the county offices of education to address immediate challenges and long-term recovery efforts related to COVID-19 in this press release: https://bit.ly/2VrI3OW

Learn more about SVCF's other #COVID19 relief initiatives: https://bit.ly/39qLQ2w

#COVID19Response #EarlyEducation #WeAreInThisTogether

In honor of #EarthDay2020, our Environmental Literacy and Sustainability Initiative shared lesson plans, professional development opportunities, and ideas for environmental activities in its monthly newsletter, the ELSI Bulletin!

Highlighted in this special issue are the San Carlos School District, Foster City Elementary in the San Mateo-Foster City School District San Mateo County Youth Commission, RethinkWaste Recology San Mateo County, Hidden Villa, Silicon Valley Clean Water, Burlingame School District, Jefferson Union High School District, and more!

Read the full issue at https://bit.ly/2S0BBMx

post_text:
If you have been looking for an opportunity to support SMC students and schools impacted by COVID-19 and school closures, today is your day.

Today, San Mateo County Office of Education joined Silicon Valley Community Foundation and Santa Clara County Office of Education in announcing the launch of the COVID-19 Education Fund.

The partnership was created to help districts provide needed distance learning, nutritional, mental health, and other support to students and their families. Learn/donate at www.smcoe.org/cep

post_text:
WEBINAR: Key Principles for Developing a Quality Distance Learning Approach | Wednesday, April 22, 2 p.m., here on Facebook Live.

This webinar is designed for teachers to virtually collaborate and learn together about some key principles and practical examples to consider as you design your lessons in a distance learning environment. Throughout the webinar you'll have an opportunity to discuss with your colleagues the ideas presented and how you can apply new learnings into your planning. This webinar is for K-12 teacher teams and can be viewed at your convenience.

post_text:
State Superintendent Tony Thurmond and the CDE are extremely concerned about the mental health and wellness of students whose lives have dramatically changed during the COVID-19 response, as well as the health of staff who are also coping with these changes.

To support students, schools, and communities during this challenging time, the CDE has gathered information regarding mental health resources, including links for students to get direct access to mental health professionals. The new “Help for Students in Crisis” web page includes crisis and warm line numbers, along with other COVID-19-related resources for providing virtual mental health services, and information for mental health providers, families, and youth: https://www.cde.ca.gov/ls/cg/mh/studentcrisishelp.asp.

post_text:
Our San Mateo County Outdoor Education naturalists bring the Outdoor Education program to students who aren’t able to attend due to the shelter-in-place order.

Note that our naturalists have been isolating and interacting with each other only for the past month. They are being safe and sheltering in place, just like you, while delivering the Outdoor Education experience to San Mateo County students.

As the livestream begins, please remember to follow our social media policy: do not post comments that are inappropriate or unrelated to the topic at hand. Posts that violate this policy will be deleted. Read our full social media policy on the About tab.

post_text:
In honor of #NationalPoetryMonth and #EarthDay2020, we are encouraging all to come up with a nature-themed haiku!

A haiku is a form of poetry that uses 17 syllables arranged in three lines in a specific order: 5 – 7 – 5. First line, 5 syllables; second line, 7 syllables; third line, 5 syllables. Write a haiku that expresses what nature means to you during this COVID-19 crisis, and your thoughts on the theme of Climate Action. Here are a couple of haikus for inspiration:

Together we build
A future for our planet
Loving space for all.
— YouthBuild USA

COVID-19 has
us sheltering at home but
my heart is in nature.

Join in the fun and share your nature-themed poems in the comments below!

#EarthDay

April 22nd is the 50th anniversary of #EarthDay!

Earth Day began as one day to voice concerns about environmental degradation happening in the United States. This year, #EarthDay2020 will draw more than 1 billion people worldwide around climate action.

Learn more at https://www.earthday.org/history.

@EarthDayNetwork

post_text: Yesterday California Governor Gavin Newsom signed an executive order addressing a variety of issues in response to the COVID-19 pandemic, including adjusting admissions requirements for the California State University system.
shared_text:
GOV.CA.GOV
Governor Newsom Signs Executive Order on Actions in Response to COVID-19 | California Governor

California Department of Education
April 17 at 5:23 PM ·

Yesterday California Governor Gavin Newsom signed an executive order addressing a variety of issues in response to the COVID-19 pandemic, including adjusting admissions requirements for the California State University system. Specifically, the CSU system will be able to waive hearing requirements to be able to make adjustments to admissions criteria for students applying this coming fall to enter as freshmen in the fall of 2021.

Read more: https://www.gov.ca.gov/2020/04/16/governor-newsom-signs-executive-order-on-actions-in-response-to-covid-19/.

The California State University system also announced it will temporarily suspend the use of ACT/SAT examinations in determining admission eligibility for all CSU campuses for the 2021-2022 academic year: https://www2.calstate.edu/csu-system/news/Pages/CSU-to-Suspend-Standardized-Testing-Requirement-for-Upcoming-Admission-Cycles.aspx.

post_text:
"As we shelter in place for the health and safety of ourselves, our families, and those in our communities, unsure when we will return to normal life again, I can only think about the kids in our state – especially our most vulnerable kids – the criticality of children’s advocacy, and lessons learned from the past."

Children Now President and San Mateo County Board of Education member Ted Lempert shares the importance of supporting all children during this unprecedented time. #COVID19

April 16 at 9:00 PM ·

State Superintendent of Public Instruction Tony Thurmond announced yesterday the creation of a new task force to close the digital divide for California students who lack access to resources such as internet connectivity and devices.

Read more: https://www.cde.ca.gov/nr/ne/yr20/yr20rel21.asp
shared_text:
California Department of Education
April 16 at 8:03 PM ·

State Superintendent of Public Instruction Tony Thurmond announced today the creation of a new task force to close the digital divide for California students who lack access to resources such as internet connectivity and devices. The Closing the Digital Divide Task Force will be co-chaired by Thurmond and California State Senator Connie M. Leyva, who is also Chair of the Senate Education Committee.

Read more: https://www.cde.ca.gov/nr/ne/yr20/yr20rel21.asp.

Our Early Learning Support Services team organizes Friday CAFE sessions for professionals involved in enhancing family-school connections and engaging families in their children’s learning.

For details and registration info, visit https://bit.ly/3erAqQ5

The 50th Anniversary of Earth Day is coming up on Wednesday April 22nd! On Friday 4/17 and Monday 4/20, SMCOE is inviting all educators to learn about Earth Day 2020 and get resources to engage students while sheltering in place.

Learn more and register on SMCOE's professional development calendar at bit.ly/SMCDistanceLearningPD.

Can’t make it to this session, but still want resources to participate? Visit tinyurl.com/ELSI-EarthDay-2020.

#EarthDay #ClimateAction #EarthDay2020

post_text:
It's the Week of the Young Child!

Did you know that teamwork develops young children's social and early literacy skills? Share how you are working together virtually or at home with #WOYC20!

Week of the Young Child, sponsored by The National Association for the Education of Young Children (NAEYC), recognizes that the early childhood years (birth through age 8) lay the foundation for children’s success in school and later life. Learn more at https://www.naeyc.org/events/woyc.

San Mateo County Health Officer Dr. Scott Morrow issued a new statement addressing the availability of data and next steps the community will take: www.smchealth.org/post/health-officer-statements-and-orders.
“Although it may not seem like it, you are doing your part, you are serving your community by limiting your contact with others. Thank you,” Dr. Morrow wrote. "...But we need to be very deliberate about our next steps. If we don’t take our next steps carefully, we will experience the worst of what this virus has to offer."

post_text:
On Friday, State Superintendent Tony Thurmond announced that the California Department of Education and the California Department of Social Services have issued new guidance that will facilitate child care for children of essential critical infrastructure workers, children at risk of abuse or neglect, and children with disabilities or special health care needs.

San Mateo County families in need of assistance can visit 4Cs of San Mateo County (Child Care Coordinating Council)'s website at https://sanmateo4cs.org/covid-19-resources/

Read more: https://www.cde.ca.gov/nr/ne/yr20/yr20rel19.asp

View the guidance on the CDE website: https://www.cde.ca.gov/sp/cd/ci/mb2006.asp
shared_text:
California Department of Education
April 10 at 4:22 PM ·

State Superintendent Tony Thurmond announced that the CDE and the California Department of Social Services have issued new guidance that will facilitate child care for children of essential critical infrastructure workers, children at risk of abuse or neglect, and children with disabilities or special health care needs. The guidance was a requirement of Governor Gavin Newsom’s Executive Order N-45-20, issued April 4, and was created in collaboration with the California Governor’s Office and the Department of Finance.

Read more: https://www.cde.ca.gov/nr/ne/yr20/yr20rel19.asp

View the guidance on the CDE website: https://www.cde.ca.gov/sp/cd/ci/mb2006.asp

Additional guidance the CDE developed in collaboration with the CDSS can be found here: https://www.cde.ca.gov/ls/he/hn/coronavirus.asp

Multilingual resources that support distance learning: https://www.cde.ca.gov/ls/he/hn/appendix1.asp#nine

post_text: What a positive story! Thank you to all who donated to support families in need in the San Mateo Union High School District.
shared_text:
San Mateo Union High School District
April 4 at 1:30 AM ·

Thank you to everyone who donated to the Cap Cares Program at Capuchino High School. Cap Cares collected $3300.00 in donations for CHS families experiencing financial hardships during school closure and Shelter in Place.

CHS staff headed out today to distribute to 28 families.

Capuchino Cares, headed up by CHS CTE and Career Coordinator Kelly McLoughlin and Vice Principal Monique de Brito Guedes , gathered names of families in need through the counselors, administration and outreach coordinators.

April 4 at 1:30 AM ·

Capuchino Cares, headed up by CHS CTE and Career Coordinator Kelly McLoughlin and Vice Principal Monique de Brito Guedes , gathered names of families in need through the counselors, administration and outreach coordinators.

post_text: Congratulations Amy for receiving a 2020 Career Technical Education scholarship from the California Association of Leaders for Career Preparation!
shared_text:
San Mateo Union High School District
April 6 at 3:32 PM ·

Hillsdale High Senior Receives CTE Scholarship

The California Association of Leaders for Career Preparation (CALCP) recently announced that Hillsdale High School Senior Amy Bruhns was the recipient of a 2020 Career Technical Education scholarship.

Hillsdale High School Drama Allison Gamlen nominated Amy for the scholarship and this is what she had to say about her: "She's an incredibly hard working student and in addition to being a triple threat Amy is also a playwright, director, and designed all the fight choreography in SHE KILLS MONSTERS."

A recording of She Kills Monster is available to view until May: https://vimeo.com/401046243/839e47b5ea?fbclid=IwAR3O1t3H6TiTTF8o2OtXkfQ0EKGA3PPa_oe6o9IwUr2k3x0m37-3GMlGaCQ

Amy is the only student in the county to be awarded this honor and she plans to study acting at Pace University in NYC in the Fall.

Learn more: https://www.calcp.org/scholarships/

post_text:
California Governor Gavin Newsom yesterday announced a major agreement between teachers, classified employees, school boards, superintendents, and principals to work together to provide distance learning to California’s students as a result of school closures due to mitigation efforts against the COVID-19 outbreak.
Labor and management organizations will work to provide students access to distance learning.

Governor Newsom: “While schools might be physically closed, class is still in session.”

“The labor and management groups understand the importance of all of us working together during this unprecedented time. The framework for this collaboration created jointly, models how we can all come together to better serve our students,” said State Superintendent of Public Instruction Tony Thurmond.

Read more: https://bit.ly/342lmn6

April 1 at 6:11 PM ·

UC to ease admission requirements | No SAT, no minimum grades due to coronavirus: https://www.latimes.com/california/story/2020-04-01/uc-to-suspend-admission-requirements-for-sat-minimum-gpas-to-help-students-during-coronavirus-crisis
text:

"It is not enough to teach our young people to be successful...so they can realize their ambitions, so they can earn good livings...Those are worthwhile goals. But it is not enough to progress as individuals while our friends and neighbors are left behind." - César Chávez

We honor César Chávez Day to commemorate the life and legacy of the civil rights activist for fighting for a better tomorrow.

#CésarChávezDay

post_text:
2020 Census continues, despite the shelter-in-place order!
For the first time ever you can complete your Census form online.
Getting counted is more important than ever before: it will bring about $1,000 per year for each resident counted to our County to pay for critical services like medical care and response to emergencies such as the COVID 19 crisis we are currently experiencing.
Participate at https://my2020census.gov/.

post_text:
San Mateo County is launching a 2020 #CensusChallenge! Census data is critical for getting federal funding for our schools, healthcare, child care and many other important community services. To participate:
Take a photo after completing the census and post to social media

Use the hashtags: #SmcCounts #EveryoneCounts and #CensusChallenge
Tag @smc_commaffairs and @SanMateoCO
Tag 5 friends to take the challenge

When more people in our community respond, that means more opportunities for you, your family, your friends and neighbors for the next 10 years – and that’s why we need your help in spreading the word! Complete the Census questionnaire today: my2020census.gov.

post_text:
Members of the public drop off donations at the County’s central collection center off of Maple Street in Redwood City.

Supplies in demand are:
• Unused N95 respirators and surgical masks. They can be opened, as long as they have not been used.
• Unopened packages of disposable gloves
• Unopened containers of hand sanitizer
• Unopened containers of disinfectants and disinfecting wipes
• Packaged, unused protective goggles

Personal protective equipment supplies can be dropped off Monday through Friday, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. at Maple Street Correctional Facility, 1300 Maple St., Redwood City.

Visit www.smcgov.org for local information and resources related to COVID-19.

shared_text:
ZEROTOTHREE.ORG
Answering Your Young Child’s Questions About Coronavirus

First 5 San Mateo County
March 23 at 8:01 PM ·

Even if you haven't talked to your toddler about #COVID19, they still may notice things have changed and have questions. It's best to keep answers short and age-appropriate:

"Why can’t we leave the house? Why can’t my friend come over to play?"

“Right now, there is a rule that families need to stay home for a little while and be together. That helps us and our friends stay healthy. I know it can be sad when we can’t see and play with friends. But there are lots of fun things we can do together at home!"

See more tips and examples from ZERO TO THREE here: https://www.zerotothree.org/resources/3265-answering-your-young-child-s-questions-about-coronavirus

post_text:
From the County of San Mateo - Government:

Stay home, stay local, stay 6 feet apart!

We love our beaches and our parks, but now is not the time to visit due to the statewide shelter-in-place order.
Congregating in these popular areas makes the shelter-in-place order less effective and continues to put all of our counties at risk of COVID-19 spread.

Recreate and get fresh air closer to home — 6 feet apart.

More here: www.smcgov.org.

For Redwood City School District Families with students in grades 3-8:

RCSD's Department of Technology and Innovation will have a technician available at the District Office from 11 am-1 pm and from 3-5pm on Tuesday and Wednesday, March 24 and 25, to assist families with checking out Chromebooks and/or hotspots for online access.

The student in Grades 3-8 does not need to be present but the parent or guardian must bring a form of identification. This check-out process will take place at the District Office, 750 Bradford St. in Redwood City, and not at your child’s(ren) school.

The Human Services Agency is committed to providing vital services to the residents of San Mateo County as our community follows the directive for social distancing and to shelter place to stem the spread of COVID-19.

In order to reduce in-person contact we offer a variety of correspondence methods to access public benefit programs. This includes by phone, email, online, mail, or utilizing a drop-box.

post_text:
To reduce the strain on students, families and educators during the COVID-19 outbreak, California Governor California Governor Gavin Newsom issued an executive order today to waive, pending federal approval, this year’s statewide testing for California’s more than 6 million students in K-12 schools.

“I appreciate the Governor’s leadership here and recognizing that under the current circumstances, the last thing our students need is to be confronted with a test,” said State Superintendent of Public Instruction Tony Thurmond. “Our districts need some relief and this decision is in the best interest of our students and our state.”

Read more: https://www.gov.ca.gov/…/governor-newsom-issues-executive-…/
shared_text:
California Department of Education
March 18 at 11:25 PM ·

To reduce the strain on students, families and educators during the COVID-19 outbreak, California Governor Gavin Newsom issued an executive order today to waive, pending federal approval, this year’s statewide testing for California’s more than 6 million students in K-12 schools.

“I appreciate the Governor’s leadership here and recognizing that under the current circumstances, the last thing our students need is to be confronted with a test,” said State Superintendent of Public Instruction Tony Thurmond. “Our districts need some relief and this decision is in the best interest of our students and our state.”

Read more: https://www.gov.ca.gov/2020/03/18/governor-newsom-issues-executive-order-to-suspend-standardized-testing-for-students-in-response-to-covid-19-outbreak/

post_text:
Breakfast Added!

Redwood City School District's (RCSD) Child Nutrition Services will continue to serve both breakfast and lunch weekdays at the Henry Ford, Garfield, and Hoover sites from 10 am to 12 noon for any child who is under 18-years old.
shared_text:
Redwood City School District
March 18 at 11:39 PM ·

Breakfast Added!

Redwood City School District's (RCSD) Child Nutrition Services will continue to serve both breakfast and lunch weekdays at the Henry Ford, Garfield, Roosevelt, and Hoover sites from 10 am to 12 noon for any child who is under 18-years old.

Your child does not need to be a student in RCSD to pick up a free school meal. Meals will be provided as drive-thru brown bags, which means families can pick them up at the school’s main front entrance and take them home. Both breakfast and lunch can be picked up at the same time.

There is no need for you to park or get out of your cars, staff will be out front ready with the meals for you to pick up. You just need to pop your trunk and staff will place the meals in your trunk. You are welcome to walk to the schools; however, please comply with staff directions, as they will be practicing social distancing.

Children and Youth 18 and under do not need to be present for complimentary meal pick up

“Food insecurity is a daily struggle for some of our students and their families and that struggle is even more difficult and complicated during the current COVID-19 emergency we’re all facing,” said State Superintendent of Public Instruction Tony Thurmond.

The California Department of Education's “CA Meals for Kids” mobile app has been updated to help students and families find meals during COVID-19-related emergency school closures. It's available on Apple, Android, or Microsoft mobile devices.

Download it here: https://www.cde.ca.gov/re/mo/cameals.asp.

post_text:
From County of San Mateo - Government: This unprecedented time calls for unprecedented action to stem the community spread of the COVID-19 virus.
County Manager Mike Callagy reminds us that San Mateo County residents are resilient and that together we will get through this, and our community’s health will be protected.

• Stay home except for essential needs.
• Call 911 for true emergencies.
• Call 211 for non-emergency, non-medical COVID-19 questions.
• Visit www.smcgov.org for more information.

post_text:
#KickPodsDay #KickButtsDay #TakeDownTobacco

Join as we spread awareness about e-cigarette and pod-based devices!

Whether you spend the day virtually participating in #KickPodsDay, #KickButtsDay, or #TakeDownTobaccoDay, we invite you to use theses hashtags to raise awareness about the harms of e-cigarettes, including pod-based devices used by our nation’s youth. Now more than ever it is the time to stop smoking or vaping, as it increases your risk for serious lung disease caused by COVID-19.

Learn more about tobacco, e-cigarettes, vapes, and pod-based devices at tobaccopreventiontoolkit.stanford.edu

post_text:
NEWS: San Mateo County Health Officer issues order directing residents to stay home.

The order limits activity, travel and business functions to only the most essential needs. Schools and other essential government functions will continue under the recommended action.

Read the order here: https://bit.ly/2WgW6Ye
Find more information here: https://cmo.smcgov.org/eoc
shared_text:
SMCGOV.ORG
www.smcgov.org

County of San Mateo - Government
March 16 at 9:44 PM ·

NEWS: San Mateo County Health Officer issues order directing residents to stay home.

The order limits activity, travel and business functions to only the most essential needs.

Health care, law and safety, and essential government functions will continue under the recommended action.

Essential businesses allowed to operate during the recommended action include:

• health care operations
• businesses that provide food, shelter, and social services, and other necessities of life for economically disadvantaged or otherwise needy individuals
• fresh and nonperishable food retailers (including convenience stores)
• pharmacies
• gas stations
• banks
• laundry businesses and services necessary for maintaining the safety, sanitation and essential operation of a residence

Read the order here: https://bit.ly/2WgW6Ye

Find more information here: https://cmo.smcgov.org/eoc

post_text:
From the CDC:

Creating a household plan now can help protect your health and the health of those you care about if there is an outbreak of COVID-19 in your community. You can start planning now:
• Talk with the people who need to be included in your plan.
• Plan ways to care for those who might be at greater risk for serious complications.
• Talk with your neighbors about emergency planning.
• Identify aid organizations in your community that you can contact for support.
• Create an emergency contact list.

Get more information about creating a household plan of action: https://bit.ly/2TrXBRE

text:
From the CDC:

Creating a household plan now can help protect your health and the health of those you care about if there is an outbreak of COVID-19 in your community. You can start planning now:
• Talk with the people who need to be included in your plan.
• Plan ways to care for those who might be at greater risk for serious complications.
• Talk with your neighbors about emergency planning.
• Identify aid organizations in your community that you can contact for support.
• Create an emergency contact list.

Get more information about creating a household plan of action: https://bit.ly/2TrXBRE

Here are four simple prevention tips you and your family can take for COVID-19 from the California Department of Public Health:

- Avoid touching eyes, nose, or mouth with unwashed hands
- Avoid close contact with people who are sick
- Stay away from work, school, or other people if you become sick

Visit cdph.ca.gov for more resources.

Join us in celebrating National School Breakfast Week! Did you know that the School Breakfast Program began as a pilot program more than 50 years ago? Studies show that kids do better in school, and have higher intakes of important nutrients such as dietary fiber, B vitamins and calcium when they eat breakfast.

Visit www.fns.usda.gov/tn/sbp-materials for tips and activities to help your school celebrate!

shared_text:
CSAC.CA.GOV
Cal Grant Handbook - California Student Aid Commission

Youth Law Center
February 27 at 11:37 PM ·

For the first time, the California Student Aid Commission will be sharing that youth in juvenile facilities across the state of CA can get financial aid for college. Yesterday, CSAC updated their Cal Grant Handbook, an important tool used by teachers, counselors, and administrators, to say that youth in juvenile facilities who are under the jurisdiction of the juvenile court are not incarcerated, and therefore are indeed eligible for Cal Grant funding. YLC has been working with CSAC to clarify this issue and ensure that this population of aspiring scholars does not get overlooked. This change is important because it opens up more financial aid funding sources for youth in juvenile facilities; youth can get additional funding for books and supplies, as well as for living expenses upon release. Youth who are in facilities long-term may also be able to access funding that can help them pay for a four-year degree through the transfer entitlement program. Click below to view the updated Cal Grant Handbook.

https://www.csac.ca.gov/post/cal-grant-handbook

shared_text:
SMCOE.ORG
www.smcoe.org

First 5 San Mateo County
February 26 at 8:14 PM ·

The San Mateo County Child Care Partnership Council (CCPC) is now recruiting new members to fill four vacant seats in the membership categories of:

Child Care Consumer/Parent (2 vacancies)
Child Care Provider (1 vacancy)
Public Agency (1 vacancy)

The term of membership is (4) years. Members will be asked to commit to six council meetings per year and active committee work over the term of office, as well as a commitment to leadership in assisting San Mateo County in providing for quality child care and early learning programs.

Membership Applications are due by Friday, March 6, 2020.

https://bit.ly/2uDgLuo

We especially want to encourage Child Care Consumers (parents/guardians using child care) and Family Child Care Home providers to apply!

Contact Sarah Kinahan at skinahan@smcoe.org or 650-802-5647 if you have any questions or need additional information.

Statewide, approximately four million children live in low-income families. Of those, about 450,000 children live in deep poverty — with annual income under $10,700 for a family of three. Without California’s safety net income assistance, 1.2 million more children would live in poverty.

Learn more in Children Now's 2020 California Children's Report Card. http://bit.ly/2020KidsRC #CAKidsReportCard

post_text:
“There is no future without education.”
- Rosa Parks (February 4, 1913-October 24, 2005)

Known as the "mother of the freedom movement," Rosa Parks' refusal to give up her seat sparked the Montgomery Bus Boycott, a model of nonviolent civil disobedience for the civil rights movement. Her words of wisdom and activism inspire youth everywhere to take a stand for what they believe in and build a better future.

#BlackHistoryMonth #civilrights #civics

Learn more about ELSI at http://bit.ly/2Os75to and the Sustainability Award Program at https://sustainablesanmateo.org/home/awards/

#Sustainability #EnvironmentalLiteracy
shared_text:
Sustainable San Mateo County
January 26 at 2:49 AM ·

Sustainable San Mateo County (SSMC) will honor San Mateo County Supervisor Dave Pine, the San Mateo County Office of Education’s Environmental Literacy and Sustainability Initiative, the Campaign for Fossil Free Buildings in Silicon Valley and long-time SSMC volunteer Afsoon Shahrdar at its 21st Annual Awards Dinner on Friday, July 10, for their contributions to sustainability in San Mateo County.

SSMC and the American Institute of Architects, San Mateo County Chapter, will present the Green Building Award to the Genentech Child Care Center in South San Francisco and give a Green Building Honorable Mention Award to North Block Hillsdale Shopping Center in San Mateo

California State Senator Jerry Hill will emcee the evening program, which will begin on July 10 at 5:30 p.m. in the Bayview Dining Room at the College of San Mateo, 1700 W. Hillsdale Blvd., San Mateo. Tickets are available at sustainablesanmateo.org. Sponsorships also are available; visit https://bit.ly/36soN5S, For more information, email tickets@sustainablesanmateo.org.

post_text:
Visit the County of San Mateo - Government to learn about the signs of human trafficking and how to put an end to it in San Mateo County.

#HumanTraffickingPreventionMonth #HumanTraffickingAwareness
shared_text:
County of San Mateo - Government
January 27 at 10:57 PM ·

Human trafficking happens in California, including the Bay Area and right here in San Mateo County.

Come by the Gallery Rotunda at 555 County Center in Redwood City to learn about a crime that may go unseen in plain sight: Human Trafficking.

The San Mateo County Human Trafficking Program, funded by Measure K the countywide half-cent sales tax, along with partners installed a series of six-foot high panels designed to raise awareness about human trafficking.

The panels offer tips on how to spot and report human trafficking. Simply put: it is the exploitation of another human being for money.

The panels also offer a series of action steps, such as adding the National Human Trafficking Hotline to your phone: 1-888-373-7888.

Learn more here: https://stophumantraffickingsmc.org/.

San Mateo County Sheriff's Office #SMCMeasureK #stophumantrafficking #humantraffickingawarenessmonth

Approximately 40 million people worldwide have been forced into human trafficking, 26 percent of whom are under the age of 18. More often than not, these victims include children in the foster care and juvenile justice systems, youth who have run away or are homeless, and children without lawful immigration status.

To address this issue, SMCOE and its partners help school staff recognize warning signs and support students of concern. Learn more at http://bit.ly/2TzONtE.

#HumanTraffickingPrevention

"This unit is one of the achievements I am most proud of in my teaching career. Students were proud of their work and were self-motivated and engaged. Not a single one asked what their grade was, as it didn’t matter. They knew they made a difference and they felt honored.”

Hundreds of teachers have benefitted from our San Mateo Environmental Learning Collaborative, a PAID fellowship program on designing student-centered, problem- and project-based, and solutions-oriented units that integrate environmental and social issues.

Learn more and apply for the 2020-21 cohort at http://bit.ly/2QZ1Th6.

shared_text:
SMDAILYJOURNAL.COM
‘Humanistic opportunity’: University students and incarcerated youth benefit from tutoring program

Project Change
January 7 at 4:20 PM ·

Over the last four years, College of San Mateo Project Change and Notre Dame de Namur University English Department have collaborated to help young people in the juvenile hall become college students. To further enhance the college experience, NDNU students studying sociology and criminal justice have joined the students in juvenile hall in the classroom to jointly take English courses and offer tutoring services. It has been a life changing experience for students to recognize their similarities rather than differences-everyone in that classroom is a college student; it demystifies what that means.

This is a great article highlighting the deeply impactful work Professor Pearl Bauer and the NDNU students and faculty have done to help our students in Project Change at the SMC juvenile hall accomplish. What a great start to 2020!

https://www.smdailyjournal.com/news/local/humanistic-opportunity-university-students-and-incarcerated-youth-benefit-from-tutoring/article_0fcb284e-2ead-11ea-870c-6bf7c1c887b0.html

"We know that Juul is using marketing and product design to directly target youth, and the rate in San Mateo County is particularly significant."

- San Mateo County Board of Education President Hector Camacho speaks with NBC Bay Area on a lawsuit against JUUL seeking damages for Juul’s marketing strategy, advertising, and product design, which have targeted minors, especially preteens and teenagers, resulting in increased use of electronic cigarettes (e-cigarettes) by youth in San Mateo County.

Parents shouldn't have to choose between finding safe care for their children and the stability of their families. Build Up for San Mateo County's Children is an initiative designed to grow and improve the supply of child care and preschool facilities in San Mateo County. Learn more here.
.

California Department of Education
December 5, 2019 at 4:31 PM ·

State Superintendent Tony Thurmond announced that public comment is now open for the draft California Strengthening Career and Technical Education for the 21st Century Act (Perkins V) State Plan. The plan was developed by the CDE, California State Board of Education, and California Community Colleges Chancellor’s Office.

Read more: https://www.cde.ca.gov/nr/ne/yr19/yr19rel81.asp
